final_answer.precision_note: Limiting data are 3 s.f. (0.150 mol dm-3); concentration reported to 3 s.f.

method: Convert the NaOH volume to dm3 because c = n/V uses V in dm3: 23.40 cm3 = 0.02340 dm3. Moles of NaOH used: n(NaOH) = c×V = 0.150 × 0.02340 = 0.00351 mol. From H2SO4 + 2NaOH → Na2SO4 + 2H2O, 2 mol NaOH react with 1 mol H2SO4, so n(H2SO4) = 0.00351/2 = 0.001755 mol. The acid volume is 25.00 cm3 = 0.02500 dm3, so c(H2SO4) = n/V = 0.001755/0.02500 = 0.0702 mol dm-3.
checks: Acid concentration is lower than NaOH concentration because fewer moles of acid are present for a similar volume (due to 1:2 stoichiometry), so 0.0702 mol dm-3 is reasonable.
Back-calculate: moles H2SO4 = 0.0702×0.02500 = 0.001755 mol; required NaOH = 2×0.001755 = 0.00351 mol, matching the titration moles.
